THIS CONCEPT PLAN DESCRIBES A PROJECT TO ADDRESS AND RESTORE IMPACTS TO WETLANDS AT QUARLES POND. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS THE RESTORATION OF WETLAND ACREAGE IMPACTED DURING PREVIOUS EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE. THE WETLANDS TO BE RESTORED INCLUDE EMERGENT, SCRUB-SHRUB AND FORESTED WETLANDS. FORESTED BUFFERS WILL ALSO BE SUPPLEMENTED AND RE-ESTABLISHED AS PRACTICABLE. PLANT SPECIES USED IN THE PROJECT HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED IN REMNANT WETLANDS AT QUARLES POND AND INCLUDE NATIVE SPECIES THAT HAVE BEEN NOTED AS HISTORICAL AND CURRENT DOMINANTS AT THE SITE OR ARE NATIVE TO THE AREA.  PLANTING WILL OCCUR IN ZONES TO ACCOMMODATE APPROPRIATE WETLAND VEGETATION OVER A PERIOD OF THREE PLANTING INSTALLMENTS. THE SITE WILL INITIALLY BE DRAWN DOWN FOR BETTER ESTABLISHMENT OF
THE SUBMERGED AQUATIC VEGETATION. AFTER THE GROW-IN PERIOD IS COMPLETE, NORMAL WATER LEVELS WILL BE RESTORED AND THE PROPOSED FORESTED/SCRUB-SHRUB AREAS WILL BE PLANTED WITH WOODY VEGETATION PRIOR TO THE BEGINNING OF THE 2010 GROWING SEASON. THIS PLANTING WILL BE FOLLOWED BY THE PLANTING OF THE LOW MARSH AREA AS SOON AS THE EMERGENT PLANT MATERIAL CAN SAFELY BE TRANSPLANTED. SUBMERGED AQUATIC VEGETATION WILL BE PLANTED IN AREAS OF THE POND OVER 1' DEEP AT NORMAL POOL, WHILE LOW MARSH EMERGENT PLANTING WILL OCCUR IN SHALLOW WATER BELOW NORMAL POOL ALONG THE FRINGE OF THE POND. THESE PLANTINGS WILL MIMIC THE ADJACENT WETLANDS IN PLANT MATERIAL, DOMINATED BY THREEWAY SEDGE, ARROW ARUM, AND SPATTERDOCK. AREAS RECEIVING FREQUENT INUNDATION WILL BE TYPIFIED BY SCRUB-SHRUB PLANTINGS ALONG THE PERIMETER, CONSISTING OF BUTTONBUSH, MARSH MALLOW, WINTERBERRY, AND HIGHBUSH BLUEBERRY. PORTIONS OF THE SITE WILL
BE GRADED DOWN TO ELEVATIONS SUITABLE FOR SCRUB-SHRUB AND FORESTED WETLAND ESTABLISHMENT. RESTORED FORESTED WETLANDS WILL BE MADE UP OF SIMILAR SPECIES IN NEARBY FORESTED WETLANDS, CONSISTING OF RED MAPLE, BLACK GUM, AND PIN OAK. UPLAND BUFFERS WILL BE RESTORED WHERE CURRENT BUFFERS ARE DEFICIENT

Case Closure Memorandum and Termination Letter Signed on 1/4/2011.  Letter states that the order will terminate 30 days from date of letter (dated 01/04/2011)

ADDITIONAL COMMENTS:
This order was written in response to a violation of the State Air Pollution Control Board Consumer Product Rule in 9VAC5-45.

These rules are developed to comply with SIP requirements and often have the potential to apply to nontraditional stationary sources, such as, sources that are not located within Virginia (manufacturers and suppliers of products) and multiple retail store chains (distributors of products).  The actual emissions from consumer products usually cannot be attributed to a single location, since they are used wherever the consumer takes them after purchase.

For this reason they are applicable only in VOC Emissions Control Areas designated in 9VAC5-20-206 and specifically referenced in the rule.  Currently, the rule only applies in the Northern Virginia and Fredericksburg VOC Control Areas.  Although these areas reside within the DEQ Northern Region, future violations and orders will be applicable in multiple VOC Control Areas and across regional boundaries as nonattainment designation and the SIP change.

Therefore, DE decided that this Order (the first related to the Consumer Products rule) should be written in Central Office and that the related compliance and enforcement files will also remain with and be managed by Central Office staff.

The actual emissions from consumer products usually cannot be attributed to a single location, since they are used wherever the consumer takes them after purchase.

For this reason they are applicable only in VOC Emissions Control Areas designated in 9VAC5-20-206 and specifically referenced in the rule.  Currently, the rule only applies in the Northern Virginia and Fredericksburg VOC Control Areas.  Although these areas reside within the DEQ Northern Region, future violations and orders will be applicable in multiple VOC Control Areas and across regional boundaries as nonattainment designation and the SIP change.

ADDITIONAL COMMENTS:
In a letter dated 10/20/11, DTCC says that it expects to complete constuction and eliminate dischage by May 2012.  Permit expires May 2012.  DTCC said it anticipates violating both the 12/1/11 complete construction deadline and the 12/31/11 decommission plant deadline. Enc_Additional_Comments:
1. Enter into contract with Engineering Consultant to perform study
of problems. July 15, 2014
2. Perform Study to evaluate options to correct clarifier performance issues. Study will focus on two basic alternatives:

A. Repair/replace existing traveling bridge with similar equipment, but modify/replace sludge return system with reliable system.
B. Replace traveling bridge system with alternative equipment, including sludge removal system.
The study will also address alarms and notifications of alarm conditions to plant operators. While the study will focus on the clarifiers, operations of adjacent units will be considered as well. The goal is to optimize plant performance. Nov 15, 2014
3. BCSA will submit the study to DEQ for concurrence with the study's recommendations. BCSA will also evaluate funding options based on cost estimates presented.Dec 15, 2014
4. BCSA will procure an Engineering Design Consultant to design the selected alternative from the study. Jan 15, 2015
5. Consultant will design improvements. Plans will be submitted to BCSA for review (along with regulatory review/funding agencies as necessary). Plans will be finalized based on review
comments. BCSA will finalize funding for project at this time. Sep 30, 2015
6. BCSA will advertise the project for construction, review bids, evaluate bids, and award a contract for construction as required. This step may be omitted if BCSA contracts for work without a formal procurement process. This item depends on the level of funding needed to complete work. Dec 15, 2015
7. Project improvements will be constructed. Work components will be tested (as required) and placed into service. 9-Month construction time estimated (maximum). September 30, 2016

Mr. Settles did not show up as planned.  2/26/2013 - I was able to speak with Mr. Settles for the first time.  Discussed site status, and explained current non-compliance.  I also brought him up to speed on past non-compliance.  He thought he had paperwork to clear up the past non-compliance.  Site Visit Log given to Compliance staff to follow-up on new issues.       Mr. Pinkesh Patel, made efforts to bring facility back into compliance through 2012, but sold the facility to Mr. Andrew Kevin Settles on September 11, 2012, due to economic hardship.  Consequently, White Lotus LLC went out of business.  White Lotus LLC was defunct according to Virginia SCC online records, and has now been purged.  Enforcement has tried unsuccessfully to contact Mr. Patel, due to unanswered mail, and disconnected phone.  The Facility has not been in operation since June 01, 2006, according to Mr. Patel, DEQ inspectors, and Registration forms. The release investigation was the last remaining unresolved issue from White Lotus LLC, and the PC would be later closed under the new owner in 2014.
On September 12, 2012 DEQ received a Notification for Underground Storage Tanks, Form 7530-2, changing the ownership to Andrew Kevin Settles (<U+FFFD>Mr. Settles<U+FFFD>).  The new owner has no apparent ties to the former.  The USTs remain temporarily closed in ground, and unused by Mr. Settles at this time.  PC 2012 <U+FFFD> 2023 was closed out on March 18, 2014, while M

RP called 4/13/17; 4/7/17 letter explains Town's efforts to correct E. coli problem. Phone call 8/3/17 discuss disinfection options with Jeff Jones - Scott Erhart of Dewberry & Davis is looking at chlorination as alternative; have swithced out everything in UV system and still have problems; are looking at cost estimates; have fixed DO issue with recirculation; have done plant upgrade; have fixed infiltration issues & therefore have dropped flow.  In 8/17/17 phone call, Clarksville said that they expect to decide whether to convert to chlor/dechlor within 30-60 days.  I said that if they choose that solution we may do an order. In 12/19/17 phone call, Jeff Jones (Town Manager, 434-374-8177) said that E. coli numbers still are not good and that he will meet with Scott Erhart of Dewberry & Davis about planning to convert to chlor/dechlor.  He also said DO performance is good lately.  He will send me a letter by the end of the year with specific plans.  We talked about doing an order or a LOA. Left VM 2/22/18.  In 3/6/18 phone convesation, Jeff Jones said that the Town has applied for a grant for a PER for conversion to chlorination.  Draft ERP sent to DE 3/6/18; concurrence 3/12/18. Permit condition 11 (9VAC5-80-1180, 9VAC5-50-260, 9VAC5-50-80) - Visibile emission limit is capped at 5% opacity, but VEE report received 8/16/19 observed a range from 5-15%, with a 6 min average high of 10%, for emergency generator G-1.  
Warning letter was sent on 1/22/19: "The engine-generator (Ref. No. G-1) was started up during the October 18, 2018 FCE. Visible emissions at the time of the inspection appeared to exceed the 5 percent opacity limit of this Condition. Based on the observations made during the inspection, it appeared that EPA Method 9 may be needed. On October 23, 2018, DEQ personnel (Cameron Stewart, Justin Wilkinson, and Paul Foxwell) conducted a Visible Emissions Evaluation (VEE) of the engine-generator (Ref. No. G-1). The VEE was conducted from 1100 -1120 EST. During this observation period, the facility had multiple 6-minute averages that exceeded the 5 percent opacity limit of this Condition. The highest 6-minute average opacity during the observation period was 21.7. The lowest 6-minute average opacity during the observation period was 16.7. Visible emission observation forms and a data summary table are attached to this inspection report. Based on the observations made during the VEE, the facility appears to be out of compliance with this Condition." Case assigned to BDH. -- 9/24/19, BDH

IRTC awaiting MM/TF signature. -- 6/30/20, BDH.

This Order allows the Waste Management Parties, Host and Moran to continue barging leachate from the Tidewater Tank Terminal in Chesapeake to a treatment facility in New Jersey. There are no violations identified, instead this Order is based on the authority in Va. Code 10.1-1402(18) allowing the Waste Management Board to "make separeate orders... it deems necessary to meet any emergency to protect public health... and the environment from the release or imminent threat of release of waste." There is also no ERP as this Order was agreed upon by both parties from the onset as a way to replace the variance in place, allowing leachate transport by barge, until its expiration on 12/31/2016 (it was extended pursuant to its terms until execution of this Order).

In 2006, Pepsi conducted a voluntary internal environmental audit by a third party auditor covering 310 facilities.  The Newport News facility audit was conducted April 26, 2007.  The audit indicated the need for air permitting of 2 #2 oil/NG boilers.  DEQ issued an air permit July 11, 2007 for the boilers.  DEQ issued the NOV August 6, 2007 for construction of the 2 boilers without an air permit.  Based upon DEQ Enforcement Guidance No. 1-2006, that the violation was discovered by a corporation-wide voluntary audit, no further enforcement action was recommended and the case was dereferred.  All related files in ECM under air facility number 61527.

Permit 395 was a Department of Health permit issued to Naval Amphibious Base, Little Creek, on January 18, 1983.  The permit was for a solid waste transfer station.  When the transfer station ownership was transferred to Naval Pubic Works Center, Norfolk, a new permit was issued, 541, by the Va Dept of Waste Management following transfer of waste regulations from the Department of Health on December 21, 1988.  The new permit was required because the Navy did not think it could meet the compliance date of July 1, 1992 for facilities operating under the Dept of Health permit.

Appendix A of the 2011 Order  and 2012 Amendment superseded and canceled by 03/19/14 Amendment to Consent Order (BR13-1103).
Appendix A of the 2011 Order superseded and canceled by 08/13/12 Amendment to Consent Order (BR12-1204).

Refer to BR13-1103 (Open Enforcement Action). On December 15, 1975, the Town of Farmville (Farmville) was granted a permit to operate a sanitary landfill (Facility) by the Virginia Department of Health, predecessor-in-interest to DEQ. Farmville reports that waste has not been received at the Facility since September 1990. 
Farmville was subject to a Consent Order dated July 9, 2007 (2007 Order) for post-closure care that included completion of a Corrective Action Plan (CAP). Farmville failed to complete the CAP and was issued NOV-09-09-BRRO-L-007, dated September 16, 2009. The 2007 Order was subsequently replaced by a Consent Order dated July 6, 2011 (2011 Order; BR09-1004) to resolve the violation. DEQ issued an Amendment to the 2011 Order on August 13, 2012 (2012 Amendment; BR12-0412) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance. DEQ issued a second Amendment on March 19, 2014 (2014 Amendment; BR13-1103) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance and the 2012 Amendment. The 2014 Amendment provides the most current Schedule of Compliance, and is the effective enforcement action. The underlying administrative terms of the 2011 Order also remain operative.

Appendix A of the 2011 Order and 2012 Amendment superseded and canceled by 03/19/14 Amendment to Consent Order (BR13-1103).
Appendix A of the 2011 Order superseded and canceled by 08/13/12 Amendment to Consent Order (BR12-1204).

Refer to BR13-1103 (Open Enforcement Action). On December 15, 1975, the Town of Farmville (Farmville) was granted a permit to operate a sanitary landfill (Facility) by the Virginia Department of Health, predecessor-in-interest to DEQ. Farmville reports that waste has not been received at the Facility since September 1990. 
Farmville was subject to a Consent Order dated July 9, 2007 (2007 Order) for post-closure care that included completion of a Corrective Action Plan (CAP). Farmville failed to complete the CAP and was issued NOV-09-09-BRRO-L-007, dated September 16, 2009. The 2007 Order was subsequently replaced by a Consent Order dated July 6, 2011 (2011 Order; BR09-1004) to resolve the violation. DEQ issued an Amendment to the 2011 Order on August 13, 2012 (2012 Amendment; BR12-0412) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance. DEQ issued a second Amendment on March 19, 2014 (2014 Amendment; BR13-1103) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance and the 2012 Amendment. The 2014 Amendment provides the most current Schedule of Compliance, and is the effective enforcement action. The underlying administrative terms of the 2011 Order also remain operative.

01252021 Call with RP; These are emergency generators that were on site, qualifying as construction (i.e. re-location). Recently applied for a permit modification with James Kyle, but they may actually need a portable permit rather than a stationary permit. DEQ permitting has been permitting them via policy interpretation. The generators are DOT approved for transport, on trailers and ready for re-location; not permanently placed ( portable / mobile sources). Generators are used to replace power during storm events and flexibly moved and used between facilities in different states.  Currently using new EHS tracking software for location and operation of sources. Brought the units to Virginia from other facilities (one from Ohio / one Arkansas) arriving in January of 2016 for a storm event. The have quick connection capability in preparation for a storm and are currently connected to facility power infrastructure. Boars head plans to keep them connected and located in Virginia until needed elsewhere.  Run time is approximately 11 hours annually (PM) for the purpose of ensuring serviceability. They havent been used for power since being located in Virginia.  Next step - draft civil charge only ERP.

05/04/2020: Operating without a permit.  There are five wells at the Facility, four active and one inactive; there are four poultry houses; last flock size 117,000 birds; estimated groundwater withdrawal is  2,819,972 gallons per year and 760,390 gallons per month.
05/14/2020: RP called to discuss the NOV.  RP said that our estimates may be accurate for consumption but not cooling.  Will provide more accurate data.  Call scheduled for May 15, 2020, but RP may not make it due to planting corn.
05/15/2020:  Spoke with Mr. Thompson.  Cordial and cooperative conversation.  He will have Cole Bundick (Farm Assistant) call to discuss water use data.  Agreed to install meters at the well# 3 and Well #4 in the middle of July (Wells #1 and #2 are already metered).  Irrigation uses estimated 12,000 gallons a year.  Well five serves three residences, approximately 5 people.
5/29/2020: Spoke with the RP about an update to the water usage data.
06/01/2020: Called to let me know that Cole Bundick is not as informed on the water withdrawal as he thought and will not call be calling.  Reminded him again that all wells need to have a meter, not just the water supplying the chicken houses.  He was frustrated about that but said he will install the meters.
7/23/2020: Called the RP.  RP said the meters are scheduled to be installed by the end of next week.
8/03/2020: Need to order a larger meter.  New chickens arrived, 118,000 Birds.
8/20/2020: Draft ERP circulated for comment.
8/28/2020: Has found a meter to fit.  Will install after chickens have left.  Will not install a meter on each well and that the data in the chicken house should suffice.  Continues to dispute estimated usage.
8/31/2020: Jane Thompson called.  Discussed the NOV.  Will send withdrawal estimates.
9/3/2020: Jane Thompson submitted estimated water withdrawal data.

NOV No. NOV-001-0320-WA issued 03/23/2020 for the unpermitted discharge of sewage to state waters.  Sewage from a private mobile home park is collected through a lateral line and directed to the public sewage collection system.  The discharges occurred due to damage caused by debris (trees, logs, etc.) hitting and hanging on the private sewer lateral aerial crossing of the South Fork Powell River during a flood event.  Once it was determined that the sewer lateral was privately owned, Town personnel contacted the Property Manager for Riggs Rental, LLC, owner of the trailer court.  Repair of the aerial crossing could not be done until water levels receded.  Removal of debris was completed.  Pipe was ordered on March 30, 2020, but there was a delay in being able to get delivery of pipe required to meet specifications such that it could be connected to the Town of Big Stone Gaps sewage collection system.  The Town completed a temporary repair on May 12, 2020.  The permanent replacement and connection of the new pipe aerial crossing to the Towns sewage collection system was completed on May 14, 2020.  IRTC completed by letter dated July 9, 2020.

Refer to BR13-1103 (Open Enforcement Action). On December 15, 1975, the Town of Farmville (Farmville) was granted a permit to operate a sanitary landfill (Facility) by the Virginia Department of Health, predecessor-in-interest to DEQ. Farmville reports that waste has not been received at the Facility since September 1990. 
Farmville was subject to a Consent Order dated July 9, 2007 (2007 Order) for post-closure care that included completion of a Corrective Action Plan (CAP). Farmville failed to complete the CAP and was issued NOV-09-09-BRRO-L-007, dated September 16, 2009. The 2007 Order was subsequently replaced by a Consent Order dated July 6, 2011 (2011 Order; BR09-1004) to resolve the violation. DEQ issued an Amendment to the 2011 Order on August 13, 2012 (2012 Amendment; BR12-0412) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance. DEQ issued a second Amendment on March 19, 2014 (2014 Amendment; BR13-1103) to extend the timeline of the 2011 Orders Schedule of Compliance and the 2012 Amendment. The 2014 Amendment provides the most current Schedule of Compliance, and is the effective enforcement action. The underlying administrative terms of the 2011 Order also remain operative.
